Article Engineering of sulfate ions migration in Fe2O3-doped NiSO4/Al2O3 catalysts to enhance the selective trimerization of propylene Xu Liu a Yu Ling a b Xiao Chen a * Changhai Liang a * a Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering School of Chemical Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian Liaoning 116024 China Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, Liaoning, China b Sinopec Ningbo New Material Research Institute Co., Ltd., Ningbo 315207, Zhejiang, China Sinopec Ningbo New Material Research Institute Co., Ltd. Ningbo Zhejiang 315207 China Sinopec Ningbo New Material Research Institute Co., Ltd., Ningbo 315207, Zhejiang, China * Corresponding author. Propylene, a readily accessible and economically viable light olefin, has garnered substantial interest for its potential conversion into valuable higher olefins through oligomerization processes. The distribution of products is profoundly influenced by the catalyst structure. In this study, Fe2O3-doped NiSO4/Al2O3 catalysts have been meticulously developed to facilitate the selective trimerization of propylene under mild conditions. Significantly, the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst demonstrates an enhanced reaction rate (48.5 mmolC3/(gcat.·h)), alongside a high yield of C9 (~ 32.2%), significantly surpassing the performance of the NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst (C9: ~24.1%). The incorporation of Fe2O3 modifies the migration process of sulfate ions, altering the Lewis acidity of the electron-deficient Ni and Fe sites on the catalyst and resulting a shift in product distribution from a Schulz-Flory distribution to a Poisson distribution. This shift is primarily ascribed to the heightened energy barrier for the β-H elimination reaction in the C6 alkyl intermediates on the doped catalyst, further promoting polymerization to yield a greater quantity of Type II C9. Furthermore, the validation of the Cossee-Arlman mechanism within the reaction pathway has been confirmed. It is noteworthy that the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits remarkable stability exceeding 80 h in the selective trimerization of propylene. These research findings significantly enhance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying olefin oligomerization reactions and provide invaluable insights for the development of more effective catalysts. Graphical Abstract The incorporation of Fe2O3 with NiSO4/Al2O3 catalysts modifies the migration process of sulfate ions, altering the Lewis acidity of the electron-deficient Ni and Fe sites on the catalyst and boosting the selective trimerization of propylene. Keywords Propylene trimerization Fe2O3-doped NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst Sulfate ions migration Poisson distribution Cossee-Arlman mechanism 1 Introduction The oligomerization of light olefins (C2–C5) is a crucial process for generating a diverse array of hydrocarbon compounds [1,2]. Particularly in light of the swift advancements in coal-to-olefins, propane dehydrogenation, and advanced cracking technologies, the burgeoning production capacity of light olefins has transformed olefin oligomerization into an exceptionally effective means of optimizing their efficient utilization [3–5]. In recent years, the high-value products through the oligomerization of propylene have garnered widespread attention. The straight-chain and branched high-quality olefins resulting from propylene oligomerization find extensive industrial applications, being utilized in agricultural chemicals, thermoplastic resins, polymer films, surfactants, plasticizers, lubricant additives, and as molecular weight regulators [6,7]. Propylene oligomerization presents an opportunity to convert plentiful and inexpensive propylene into valuable organic synthetic intermediates. Among these, oxo alcohols resulting from propylene trimers are predominantly used as plasticizers for polyvinyl chloride, while propylene tetramers are widely employed in the synthesis of alkyl ethoxylate nonionic surfactants. The outlook for propylene oligomerization products is promising [8]. Controlling the carbon chain length of the products is a pivotal concern in light olefin oligomerization. Since the discovery of the “nickel effect” by Ziegler et al. [9], nickel-loaded porous materials have become significant catalysts for olefin oligomerization reactions. Consequently, nickel-based heterogeneous catalysts are viewed as a promising option. Currently, Ni-loaded oxides, zeolites, nickel-containing metal-organic frameworks, and various other nickel-based porous materials are extensively employed in the realm of olefin oligomerization research [10]. Noteworthily, mesoporous materials impregnated with nickel sulfate exhibit exceptionally high catalytic efficiency in light olefin oligomerization [9,11]. Besides, various metal complexes such as Ti, Fe, Zr, Zn, Ca, Co, and other transition metals are extensively explored for catalyzing the oligomerization of light olefins [12–15]. Metal coordination catalysis at metal sites is observed to be milder compared to acid catalysis at Brönsted acid sites, allowing for flexible control of product carbon chain length and fewer side reactions like cracking and aromatization [7,16–19]. Therein, nickel, as an active site for olefin oligomerization reactions, typically yields dimers [9,20–22]. In contrast, when iron serves as the active site, the trimer content in the products is often relatively higher, albeit with the lower reactivity and yield [23]. The mechanism behind the catalytic olefin oligomerization reactions involving these metal complexes has been a topic of debate and remains controversial in the scientific community. Therefore, further investigation into the active site states of transition metal complexes involved in catalyzing olefin oligomerization and understanding the underlying reaction mechanisms are of paramount importance. Research in this area is crucial for advancing our knowledge of these catalytic processes and their applications. Herein, we introduce Fe2O3 as a co-catalyst in NiSO4/Al2O3 samples, exploring the effects of altering the chemical environment of nickel and iron species on the propylene reaction rate and products distribution by adjusting the Ni/Fe elemental ratio. We further investigate the impact of changes in the catalyst surface structure resulting from Fe2O3 doping on the chemical environment of Ni and Fe sites, as well as the alteration in the reaction pathways of trimer (C9) products under the Cossee-Arlman mechanism. It is confirmed that the activity of propylene oligomerization reactions is linked to the electron deficiency of the Ni and Fe sites as Lewis acids. The extent of electron deficiency on the Ni sites can influence the adsorption and activation capability of propylene molecules, leading to the occurrence of an induction period in the reaction. Moreover, while the Ni sites exhibit stronger activation capabilities towards propylene molecules as active species, the C6 alkyl intermediates are more liable to undergo β-H elimination reactions from the nickel sites and consequently desorb. By contrast, the C6 alkyl intermediates on the iron sites are more stable and can further polymerize to produce additional trimers. These discoveries contribute to enhancing our comprehension of the mechanism of olefin oligomerization reactions and offer valuable insights for the rational design and development of more effective catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 catalysts The xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using commercial activated alumina powder as the carrier through the stepwise incipient wetness impregnation method. The process involved dissolving NiSO4·6H2O in deionized water and subsequently adding activated alumina powder. After stirring continuously at room temperature for 6 h, the impregnated sample underwent rotary evaporation to remove excess solvent, followed by drying in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h, and finally calcinated at 500 °C in an O₂/Ar gas flow for 4 h to obtain NiSO4/Al2O3 sample with varying Ni loadings. Furthermore, Fe(NO3)3 was loaded onto the NiSO4/Al2O3 precursor to adjust the theoretical total loading of Ni and Fe to 10 wt%. After impregnation, samples underwent the same separation and calcination steps as described above to acquire xFe2O3-NiSO4/ Al2O3 samples with different Ni and Fe ratios (where x = n(Fe)/[n(Ni) + n(Fe)], x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1; After being calcined at 500 °C, Fe(NO3)3 underwent a complete decomposition into Fe2O3, while NiSO4 was not decompose. The thermogravity-mass spectroscopy (TG-MS) profiles of NiSO4·6H2O and Fe(NO3)3 depicting this process are illustrated in Fig. S1. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was conducted using a diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα 1 radiation source (Rigaku SmartLab 9 KW). High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) images were captured using a JEOL JEM-F200 microscope. TG-MS analysis was conducted with the Discovery SDT650 TGA-MS system by TA Instruments. Samples (~10 mg) were heated at 10 °C/min in argon or oxygen (100 mL/min) up to 800 °C, while monitoring gas components with mass spectrometry. N2 physical adsorption measurements were conducted at –196 °C using an Autosorb IQ instrument from Quantachrome with an automated sorption system. A Renishaw model Raman spectrometer with a laser line of 532 nm and a power of 50 mW was employed for Raman spectroscopic observations on powdered samples. TPR analysis was carried out using a chemical adsorption analyzer (Micromeritics Autochem II 2920). Samples (~50 mg) were pretreated in argon at 500 °C for 1 h, cooled to room temperature, and then reduced in 10% H2/Ar. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements were performed using the easyXAFS300 laboratory device (easyXAFS LLC, Renton, WA), collecting Ni and Fe K-edge spectra from dilute powder samples pressed into pellets alongside standard reference materials. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using the Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with Al Ka radiation (hv = 1486.8 eV) at 150 W. Sample binding energies were calibrated using the C 1s peak at 284.6 eV as a reference. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis was conducted using a Quantachrome ChemBET-3000 adsorption analyzer. Samples (~100 mg) were pretreated at 500 °C in a helium stream for each experiment. Following a purge with 50 mL/min of helium, chemisorbed NH3 was measured by ramping the desorption temperature from 100 to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under helium flow. Pyridine (Py)-infrared (IR) analysis was performed using a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR. Samples (~15 mg) were pressed into a 15 mm disc, and the background was collected after vacuum degassing at 500 °C for 1 h. Pyridine was introduced to saturation, followed by vacuum desorption at 150 °C for 0.5 h. C3H6-temperature programmed surface reaction (TPSR)-MS analysis was carried out on a quartz reaction equipped with a mass spectrograph (GSD 320 OMNISTAR). Samples (~100 mg) were pretreated in Ar flow at 500 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, the samples were exposed to a gas mixture (20% C3H6 in Ar), and the temperature was ramped from 40 to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The C6 signal (m/z = 84) was monitored using a mass spectrometer. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic efficacy of various samples in propylene oligomerization was assessed through a fixed bed microreactor with an 8 mm diameter. A simplified diagram depicting this setup was presented in Scheme 1 . Typically, the catalyst powder obtained was formed into pellets and sifted to yield particles sized between 40–60 mesh. Subsequently, 3.0 g of these catalyst particles were taken and placed in the central isothermal zone of a tubular reactor. The catalyst underwent a pretreatment at 500 °C for 2 h under an argon gas flow to remove adsorbed water before reaching the reaction temperature. After adjusting the argon to the desired pressure, the propylene feed gas (with inert propane as an internal standard at a ratio of 9:1) was pressurized into liquid form via a hydraulic pump and introduced into the reactor. Gas phase components were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (GC7820) with a thermal conductivity detector and a dimethyl ether column, while liquid phase products were analyzed using an Agilent gas chromatograph (GC7890A) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a PONA capillary column. Propylene conversion (X), selectivity of different components (Si ), weight hourly space velocity (WHSV), and propylene consumption rate (r p) were calculated accordingly: (1) X = (n 0 – nt )/n 0 × 100% (2) S i = ni /∑ni × 100% (3) WHSV = F/W (4) r p = F × X/42 × m cat. Here, n 0 and nt represent the propylene moles before and after the reaction, respectively. ni stands for the moles of component i after the reaction, and Σni is the total moles of all components post-reaction. F denotes the propylene’s weight flow rate, W is the catalyst’s weight, and m cat. indicates the mass of catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties A series of xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 samples with varying Ni/Fe mole ratios (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1) were synthesized using a stepwise incipient wetness impregnation method, with a total metal loading of 10%, as shown in Fig. 1(a) . The XRD pattern of the NiSO4/Al2O3 sample exhibits the distinct peaks corresponding to the orthorhombic crystal structure of NiSO4 (Fig. 1(b)) [20,24]. The pattern of the Fe2O3/Al2O3 sample displays characteristic peaks attributed to α-Fe2O3 crystals at 24.1°, 33.1°, 35.6°, 40.8°, 49.4°, 54.0°, 62.4°, and 64.0°, which conform to the (012), (104), (110), (113), (024), (116), (214), and (300) reflection levels, respectively [25]. This indicates that ferric nitrate is decomposed completely to iron oxide during calcination. In contrast, the peak intensity of the xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 samples gradually diminishes along with the incorporation of Fe2O3. Specifically, in the 0.5Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, no characteristic diffraction peaks ascribed to NiSO4 or Fe2O3 are observed. It indicates that the mixture of NiSO4 and Fe2O3 enhances the metal-support interaction, resulting in a uniform dispersion on the support surface. Further characterization of the prepared 0.5Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample was carried out using HADDF-STEM. The image in Fig. 1(c) does not reveal significant lattice fringes. Combined with the EDS mapping, it is confirmed that the Ni, Fe, and S elements are well distributed within the particles. Additionally, according to the line-scanning EDS characterization (Fig. 1(d)), it is observed that the EDS profiles of Ni, Fe and S elements exhibit similar trends. Consequently, the incorporation of Fe2O3 into NiSO4 leads to their uniform dispersion. This enhancement in dispersibility may be attributed to the interaction between NiSO4 and Fe2O3. The investigation into the surface structural properties of the samples is presented in Fig. S2, which presents the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the various samples and their supports. According to the classification by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), all samples showcase type IV isotherms, indicative of mesoporous materials [26–28]. The pristine alumina support showcases an H2 hysteresis loop, pointing towards capillary condensation in bottleneck-shaped mesopores [29]. Conversely, the supported samples display H3 hysteresis loops. The N2 physical adsorption data listed in Table S1 confirms the average pore size of the samples to be ca. 4 nm, validating their mesoporous nature. The specific surface area of the Al2O3 support is 199 m2/g, with a total pore volume of 0.49 cm3/g. However, the specific surface area and total pore volume of the samples witness a significant decrease after loading. This decline is likely due to the obstruction of certain pores by NiSO4 or Fe2O3, thereby impeding the adsorption of N2 molecules. Furthermore, it becomes apparent that samples with a higher NiSO4 content exhibit diminished specific surface areas and pore volumes but larger average pore sizes. This observation suggests the uniform dispersion of NiSO4, as aligned with XRD results, which could open possibilities for the interaction between NiSO4 and Fe2O3. The interaction between sulfate ions and metal ions was investigated through H2-TPR analyses, as depicted in Fig. 2(a) . The intensity of the reduction peak in the sample exhibits a noticeable correlation with the sulfate ion content. This observation is consistent with findings by Yu et al. [30], who identified H2S during the reduction processes of NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst using TPR-MS. Hence, the shift in the reduction peak temperature in samples containing sulfate ions indicates variations in the sulfate chemical environment. In the Fe2O3/Al2O3 sample lacking sulfate ions, two faint reduction peaks are detected at 360 and 620 °C, signifying the reduction processes from Fe3+ to Fe2+ and from Fe2+ to Fe0, respectively [31,32]. Samples containing sulfate ions exhibit distinctive reduction peaks in the 400–500 °C range due to the different chemical environments of sulfate ions. The reduction temperature for SO4 2– interactions with Ni2+ is approximately 410 °C, whereas with Fe3+ at 470 °C. In the xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, a composite peak is observed, resolved into distinct reduction peaks corresponding to interactions with different metal cations. As the Fe content increases, the intensity of both reduction peaks also alters, suggesting the migration of a greater quantity of SO4 2– from Ni2+ to Fe3+ of Fe2O3. To delve deeper into the phenomenon of sulfate ions migration, the samples were further characterized using the Raman spectrometer. In Fig. 2(b), the peaks at 478 cm–1 (ν 2–SO4) and 610 cm–1 (ν 4–SO4) represent the symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations of sulfate ions, while the peaks at 986 cm–1 (ν 1–SO4) and 1078 cm–1 (ν 3–SO4) correspond to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of sulfate ions [33–35]. Upon introducing Fe2O3, the stretching vibration peaks of ν 1-SO4 and ν 3-SO4 blue-shift, indicating that these ions may have established new coordination environments within the system. The absence of peaks at 225, 250, 290, and 415 cm–1, corresponding to α-Fe2O3 characteristic peaks, in the xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample indicates that most of the Fe2O3 is non-crystalline [36,37]. Additionally, within the amorphous Fe2O3, the asymmetric stretching vibration peak of Fe–O at approximately 700 cm–1 experiences a blue shift, suggesting the emergence of new coordinations involving Fe3+. The shifts in these peaks suggest the formation of coordinate covalent bonds between SO4 2– and Fe3+. Based on the above results, assumptions are made regarding the surface structure of the samples after the incorporation of Fe2O3 (as shown in Fig. 2(c)), akin to the structure suggested by Saur et al. [38]. In hydrated nickel sulfate samples, Ni2+ sites are hypothesized to exhibit a six-coordinate geometry, where all coordination vacancies are filled by water molecules [39]. The presence of water molecules, due to solvation effects, hinders direct coordination between SO4 2– and Ni2+. After the samples undergo thermal activation, coordinated water molecules gradually dissociate, creating coordination vacancies around Ni2+. This vacancy formation enables some SO4 2– to directly coordinate with Ni2+ [40]. The doping of Fe2O3 has been demonstrated to result in some SO4 2– bonding with neighboring Fe3+, potentially inducing alterations in the coordination structures of Ni and Fe, leading to a redistribution of electrons. The influence of sulfate ion migration on the chemical environment of active species was further elucidated through XAS characterization. Fig. 3 displays the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra of xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 samples, alongside Ni foil (Ni0) and NiO (Ni2+) references. Model fitting results for all samples are displayed Table S2 and Fig. S3. Upon fitting, the first shell corresponds to the Ni–O scattering path, while the second shell represents the Ni-S/Ni scattering path. Increasing the Fe doping level results in a decrease in Ni-O coordination from 5.7 to 5.3, and an increase in Ni-S/Ni coordination from 1.3 to 1.7. The emergence of the pre-edge peak at 8333 eV in Fig. 3(a) is assigned to the dipole-forbidden but quadrupole-allowed transition (1s → 3d) [41]. With the increase in iron content, the peak energy before the edge shifts to lower values, indicating a potential alteration in the coordination structure of Ni2+. This shift corresponds to changes in the Ni-O coordination, implying that during Fe2O3 doping, sulfate ions may migrate from nickel species, leading to an overall expansion in the structure and a reduction in the coordination number of Ni species [42,43]. Additionally, as depicted in Fig. 3(a), the absorption edge of Ni undergoes a blueshift (indicated by purple arrows), implying an increase in electron cloud density around Ni2+ with rising Fe2O3 content. Correspondingly, in Fig. S4, as the ratio of SO4 2– to Fe3+ in the sample rises, the absorption edge of Fe displays a redshift, indicating a decrease in electron cloud density around Fe3+. Detailed chemical state changes were further investigated through XPS analysis on the electron binding energies of Ni 2p and Fe 2p orbitals in the samples, as depicted in Fig. 4 . Upon contrasting the Ni 2p 3/2 spectra of various samples (Fig. 4(a)), it becomes evident that solely Ni2+ species are identified across all Ni-containing samples, although some distinctions were observed. In the NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, the binding energy of Ni species is measured at 857.7 eV [44]. As the doping amount of Fe2O3 in the samples increases, the binding energy of Ni species gradually shifts towards lower energies. Specifically, in the 0.75Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, the binding energy of Ni species reaches 856.7 eV, indicating an increase in electron density due to the doping of Fe2O3. However, the binding energies of Ni species in these samples notably surpass the 855.6 eV observed in the NiO/Al2O3 sample, suggesting that the electron density of Ni species in all sulfate ions containing samples is lower than that in the NiO/Al2O3 sample. Similar trends are observed in the Fe 2p 3/2 spectra of the samples (Fig. 4(b)). In the Fe2O3/Al2O3 sample, the low energy component centered at 711.3 eV is assigned to Fe3+ species [45]. In the xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, with an escalation in the SO4 2–/Fe3+ ratio, the binding energy of Fe species marginally shifts towards higher energies, attributable to the electron-withdrawing effect of SO4 2– ions on surrounding iron ions. In the NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, the electron-withdrawing effect of SO4 2– on Ni2+ leads to electron deficiency in Ni2+ sites. Following the doping of Fe2O3 into the sample, the creation of new coordinate covalent bonds between sulfate ions and iron ions results in a decrease in the electron density of the Fe species compared to its initial state. Conversely, there is a slight increase in electron density around Ni2+, attributed to the electron-withdrawing effect of Fe3+ sharing SO4 2– ions. This confirms the electron distribution hypothesis proposed earlier. In comparison to the Fe2O3/Al2O3 sample, the binding energy of iron in the Fe2O3-SO4 2–/Al2O3 sample shifts to a higher energy level, reaching 712.4 eV. This shift suggests the presence of strongly electron-deficient Fe3+ species in this sample [46], a factor that may contribute to its catalytic activity in propylene oligomerization reactions [25]. Previous research has indicated that the surface acidity of catalysts is a critical factor that impacts the activity of olefin oligomerization reactions. In this study, we aim to assess the effect of incorporating Fe2O3 on the acidity of the samples. To delve into this impact, we conducted NH3-TPD characterization to quantify ammonia desorption on various samples and complemented this with Py-FTIR analysis to explore the distribution of Lewis acid and Brönsted acid sites. From the NH3-TPD results (Fig. 5(a) ), it is evident that the peak of ammonia desorption occurs around 240 °C, indicating a prevalence of weak acid sites on the samples. Moreover, based on the Py-FTIR spectra (Fig. 5(b)) at 150 °C desorption, the infrared signal peaks at approximately 1545 and 1450 cm–1 correspond to the stretching vibration peaks of pyridine molecules adsorbed on Brönsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites, respectively. Specific data collated in Table S3 demonstrates that the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, due to the doping of a small amount of Fe2O3, exhibited heightened total acidity, primarily attributed to an increase in Lewis acidity. As the proportion of Fe2O3 continued to rise, the acidity gradually decreased, potentially attributed to the progressive decrease of SO4 2–. 3.2 Catalytic performance 3.2.1 Evaluation of propylene oligomerization The influence of Fe2O3 doping on the propylene oligomerization activity of the NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst at 70 °C, 2.5 MPa, and 2.1 gC3/(gcat.⋅h) is shown in Fig. 6(a) . The NiSO4/Al2O3 sample achieves an initial propylene consumption rate of 48.8 mmolC3/(gcat.·h), which gradually decreased to 47.8 mmolC3/(gcat.·h) over time on stream. In contrast, the xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample displays an induction period at the onset of the reaction, followed by a gradual increase in propylene conversion until reaching a steady state. Notably, the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample exhibits exceptional catalytic performance post the induction period, maintaining a propylene consumption rate of approximately 48.5 mmolC3/(gcat.·h), surpassing the other samples. Comparative analysis across the sample series indicates that the activity of the samples diminished as the NiSO4 content decreased. Significantly, the Fe2O3/Al2O3 sample demonstrates negligible reactivity, underscoring its limited efficacy in catalyzing the propylene oligomerization reaction. For comparative purposes, Ni sites are eliminated from the top-performing sample (0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/ Al2O3) to produce the Fe2O3-SO4 2–/Al2O3 sample. It exhibits an initial propylene consumption rate of approximately 17.5 mmolC3/(gcat.·h) but deactivates after 5 h of reaction. The distribution of propylene oligomerization products on various catalyst samples is illustrated in Fig. 6(c), with oligomerization products (Cn = 3i, i = 2, 3, 4, …) predominantly present and a small fraction of olefin metathesis products (OMP) (Cn ≠ 3i, i = 2, 3, 4, …). This occurrence can be attributed to the inevitable isomerization and olefin metathesis reactions acting as side reactions under the influence of strong Lewis acid sites from transition metals [47–49]. Specifically, the Ni species demonstrate higher selectivity towards dimers (C6), with the selectivity of products progressively decreasing as the polymerization degree increases. This distribution pattern aligns with the Schulz-Flory distribution (C6 > C9 > C12 > C15) [50]. The doping of Fe2O3 notably shifts the product distribution, decreasing selectivity towards dimer (C6) while significantly enhancing selectivity towards trimer (C9) and tetramer (C12). In the Fe2O3-SO4 2–/Al2O3 sample containing solely Fe species, the selectivity for C9 and C12 rises to 43.6% and 33.8%, respectively. Evaluation of the yields of different samples (as depicted in Fig. 6(b) and Fig. S5) indicate that the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample boasts the highest yield for C9 olefin (~32.2%) and the combined C9 + C12 products (~55.0%). Therefore, the migration of sulfate ions activates the Fe sites, while a synergistic interplay between Fe and Ni sites improves the conversion of propylene reactions and enhances the selectivity towards trimers. Further analysis is conducted on the distribution of dimers and trimers in xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 samples, comparing them with the product distribution of sulfonic acid resin catalysts (a type of Brönsted acid catalyst) following the carbon cation mechanism (Table 1 ). Additionally, utilizing the HSC Chemistry 6.0 software, we computed the enthalpy, entropy, and Gibbs free energy changes for all C6 products, showcased in Table S4. Comparison of these values with the actual dimer distribution reveals that the resin-catalyzed dimer distribution closely mirrors thermodynamic equilibrium values. This alignment is attributed to Brönsted acid sites participating in the reaction without directly influencing bond formation and cleavage during the oligomerization process, where product formation adheres to thermodynamically balanced oligomerization reactions. Conversely, significant differences exist between products generated by metal sites following the Cossee-Arlman mechanism and those at thermodynamic equilibrium [22]. This discrepancy stems from propylene oligomerization catalyzed by metal sites forming coordination bonds with propylene molecules. Unlike the Brönsted acid catalysis mechanism, this pathway produces distinct metal-alkyl intermediates. Differing stabilities of these intermediates result in diverse product distributions. The trends in the variations of different types of C6 and C9 olefins in the products are visually represented in Fig. S6. Upon comparative analysis with the product distribution of sulfonic acid resin, it is noted that Type I C6 and Type I C9 are absent in the catalytic products of sulfonic acid resin but are predominantly present in metal-catalyzed products. Conversely, Type III C6 and Type III C9 are more prevalent in the catalytic products of sulfonic acid resin and less common in metal-coordinated catalytic products. This observation suggests that Type I C6 and Type I C9 are exclusively produced via the Cossee-Arlman mechanism on metal sites, whereas Type II C6 and Type II C9 could be thermodynamically stable products formed on both metal and Brönsted acid sites. Lastly, Type III C6 and Type III C9 products may be generated through metal site isomerization during the reaction or catalyzed by Brönsted acid sites [7]. Investigate the influence of Fe2O3 doping on the initial intrinsic activity of the sample through experiments with varying contact times, as depicted in Fig. 7 . Given the complexity of propylene oligomerization reactions, where primary products can undergo subsequent oligomerization reactions, we are narrowing our focus to primary reactions for analytical simplicity. Kinetic tests were carried out at low conversions. Fig. 7(a) illustrates that the primary reaction of propylene on these catalysts can be accurately represented as a pseudo first–order reaction. At a reaction temperature of 70 °C, the decreasing order of τ values is NiSO4/Al2O3 (26.6) > 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/ Al2O3 (17.4), suggesting that the addition of iron decreases the intrinsic reaction rate of propylene on Ni sites, which could be linked to the induction period of the reaction [51]. Subsequent tests involved extended contact times. In samples containing Ni species (Fig. 7(b)), at a contact time of 5 gcat./(gC3·min), the propylene conversion reached 98.3%, with a dimer selectivity of 63.4%. With increasing contact time, the propylene conversion gradually rose, with dimers further polymerizing into C9, C12, and C15+ olefins. This indicates that Ni sites exhibit higher selectivity towards dimer products, with trimers and heavier olefins resulting from further oligomerization of dimers, aligning with previous findings by Ling et al. [22]. Conversely, in samples containing Fe species (Fig. S7(a)), at a contact time of 15 gcat./(gC3·min), the propylene conversion is 67.5%, with a dimer selectivity of only 7.0% and a trimer selectivity of 43.0%. Extended contact time led to an increase in conversion, while the selectivity to dimers and trimers gradually decreased, and the selectivity to C12 and C15+ olefins increased. This shift in trimers and dimers indicates that trimers were not formed through further polymerization of initially formed dimers at Fe sites, highlighting different trimerization pathways of propylene on Ni and Fe sites. Data for the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample at different contact times (Fig. 7(c)) show a decrease in dimer selectivity and a gradual increase in trimer and high carbon olefin selectivity as contact time increases. It is noteworthy that the trimer selectivity surpasses that of the pure Ni sample, signifying a synergistic effect between the Ni and Fe sites. Examination of the distribution of C9 products (Figs. 7(d), (e) and Fig. S7(b)) indicates that the proportion of Type I C9 in the products catalyzed by the Ni sites is notably higher than that by the Fe sites. However, in the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, the proportion of Type I C9 falls between these two values. This disparity further validates that the doping of Fe2O3 influences the pathway of C9 formation. For a more comprehensive analysis of the olefin oligomerization reaction network, detailed characterization of the products was carried out. The overall distribution of products under contact times of 5 and 30 gcat./(gC3·min) by the 0.25 Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample was analyzed using 2D HSQC (heteronuclear single quantum coherence) and 1H-NMR spectroscopy. The 2D HSQC spectra, depicted in Figs. 8(a), (b) , the signal peaks represent the correlation between the chemical shift of protons (1H) and the directly bonded carbon nuclei (13C). Products obtained with shorter contact times exhibit an elevation in both the quantity and intensity of the carbon-hydrogen correlation peaks of double bond carbons in comparison to products subjected to longer contact times. Conversely, with increased contact time, the quantity and intensity of the carbon-hydrogen correlation peaks of methyl carbons become more pronounced. By analyzing the corresponding 1H-NMR spectra (Figs. 8(c), (d)), the percentage content of hydrogen on alkene double bond carbons, methyl carbons, methylene carbons, and methine carbons was determined. It is apparent that as contact time increased, the relative hydrogen content on alkene double bond carbons decreased from 10.1% to 7.0%. The prolonged contact time results in further olefin oligomerization, leading to an elongation of the carbon chain and consequently reducing the hydrogen content on double bond carbons for products of identical mass. Simultaneously, the escalation in contact time also causes an uptick in hydrogen content on methyl carbons (from 44.0% to 47.7%), signifying an augmented branching degree of the overall products. These observations from the 1H-NMR spectra align with the findings from 2D HSQC spectra. The analysis using nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy indicates that prolonged contact times results in further oligomerization reactions of propylene, leading to increased branching of products as the carbon chain lengthened. This phenomenon may be linked to the specific structural characteristics of propylene molecules and the underlying reaction mechanisms. The GC × GC-MS and GC-MS spectra (Fig. 8(e) and Fig. S8) of the oligomerization products at a contact time of 5 gcat./(gC3·min) complement each other, suggesting a broad distribution of carbon numbers in the products. The presence of significant configurational isomerism indicates a highly complex chemical environment of carbon and hydrogen, particularly within the C9 and C12 range. The analysis of the GC × GC-MS spectrum reveals the product distribution (refer to Table S5), showing that the products are mainly monounsaturated hydrocarbons with a minimal content of dienes (~0.3%), possibly stemming from olefin metathesis reactions. Notably, the absence of aromatic compounds in the analysis suggests the absence of olefin aromatization reactions. The oligomerization of olefins represents a form of “cascade copolymerization”, where the initial products formed can actively participate in subsequent oligomerization reactions [51]. Building upon the experimental findings detailed earlier, a theoretical framework for the propylene oligomerization reaction network is proposed in Scheme 2 . Propylene molecules coordinate and insert into metal hydrides to create metal alkyl intermediates, which subsequently undergo transformations to yield dimers (C6), trimers (C9), tetramers (C12), and higher C3n olefins, alongside other non-C3n olefins produced through olefin metathesis reactions. Notably, a divergence is observed in the propylene trimer formation mechanisms at Fe sites compared to Ni sites. At Fe sites, trimer formation is hypothesized to involve the direct insertion of propylene molecules into the Fe-C6 alkyl intermediate, rather than the alkyl intermediate undergoing β-H elimination to form dimers (C6). Conversely, at Ni sites, propylene appears to have a higher propensity to initially generate dimers (C6), followed by subsequent oligomerization steps leading to trimer formation (C9). It indicates that under the specified reaction conditions, the Ni-C6 alkyl intermediate is more prone to elimination reactions, whereas the Fe-C6 alkyl intermediate tends to undergo further oligomerization, possibly indicating variances in the stability of the M-C6 alkyl intermediates. As a result, different reaction pathways are observed for trimer formation at Fe sites compared to Ni sites. 3.2.2 The impact of metal sites on catalytic activity and reaction mechanism The acidity of catalysts serves as a crucial factor influencing the oligomerization of olefins, allowing for the modulation of catalytic activity, reaction pathways, and product distribution. Comparative data in Table S3, reveals that the predominant acid sites in the samples are Lewis acids, significantly outnumbering Brönsted acids. Subsequently, upon achieving reaction stabilization, the rate of propylene conversion in various samples exhibits a robust correlation with the acidity of Lewis acids, as depicted in Fig. 9(a) . It indicates that the key active sites catalyzing propylene oligomerization are primarily Lewis acid sites. However, despite the presence of Lewis acid sites in Fe2O3/Al2O3 sample, catalytic activity is not exhibited. Through integration of XPS data, it becomes evident that not all Lewis acid sites are capable of catalyzing propylene oligomerization. Specifically, the catalytic proficiency hinges on the electronic state of the metal sites (Lewis acids), with only highly electron-deficient metal sites (Lewis acids) demonstrating catalytic activity in propylene oligomerization. The activity of propylene oligomerization is jointly influenced by the metal species and sulfate ions, owing to the intimate relationship between the electron deficiency of metal sites and sulfate ions. The induced electron-withdrawing effect of sulfate ions directly leads to the electron deficiency of Ni and Fe sites, both of which play a crucial role in activating propylene molecules. Combining reaction activity data unveils a notable disparity in catalytic performance between Ni sites and Fe sites, with Ni sites demonstrating significantly superior performance. Intriguingly, the doping of Fe sites into the catalytic system coincides with the emergence of an induction period. Mlinar et al. [52] observed a similar induction period in propylene oligomerization experiments using Ni-Na-X catalysts, attributing it to the gradual formation of active species as Ni2+ ions migrate within different cages of X zeolite. Ling et al. [20] loaded NiSO4 onto amorphous or crystalline Nb2O5 and proposed that the induction period arises from the transfer of electrons from propylene molecules (as electron donors) to the unfilled orbitals of Ni2+ ions, leading to a change in the electronic state of the Ni2+ sites and the generation of active Ni species. However, no induction period was noted when NiSO4 was loaded onto Al2O3. With the doping of Fe species, the induction period commenced to emerge and progressively intensified with an increase in the proportion of Fe species. Consequently, the actual cause of the induction period could potentially be associated with the generation of intermediate active Ni species resulting from the inclusion of Fe species. The electron-deficient Ni2+ serves as the primary active site for propylene oligomerization, exhibiting robust electron affinity and forming π-adsorption with propylene, thereby facilitating the activation of propylene molecules. As delineated in Fig. 9(b), the relationship between the binding energy of Ni and the induction period illustrates that as the binding energy of Ni decreases, both the increase in conversion rate during the induction period and the duration of the induction period also increase. This correlation can be attributed to the differing adsorption and activation capabilities of Ni species towards propylene. When the electron-deficient nature of Ni weakens, its adsorption and activation capabilities towards propylene also diminish, resulting in the induction period. Moreover, the Fe2O3 doping modifies the distribution of oligomerization products, as illustrated in Fig. 9(c). In the NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, the products adhere to a Schulz-Flory distribution. However, with an escalated Fe content, the selectivity for trimeric and tetrameric products rises, surpassing the Schulz-Flory distribution and gradually transitioning to a Poisson distribution [53,54]. This shift in product distribution is intrinsically tied to the reaction pathways of Ni sites and Fe sites. To validate this pathway variation, C3H6-TPSR-MS experiments were conducted on different samples under varying environmental pressures. By analyzing the m/z = 84 signal peak position, the desorption behavior of the intermediate product C6 at various active sites was determined [20,55,56]. The peaks of the C6 signal on different samples are depicted in Fig. 9(d). In the NiSO4/Al2O3 sample, the C6 signal peak appeared around 70 °C, aligning with the reaction temperature employed in fixed-bed experiments. For the xFe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 samples, with an increasing proportion of Fe elements, the C6 alkene peak position gradually shifts to higher temperatures (approximately 130 °C). This shift could stem from challenges encountered in the β-H elimination of the C6 alkyl intermediate at Fe3+ sites at a 70 °C reaction temperature, impeding C6 alkene formation. Consequently, the M-C6 alkyl intermediates continue to undergo further reactions with propylene, yielding C9 olefins. This observation underscores the disparity in stability between Ni-C6 alkyl intermediates and Fe-C6 alkyl intermediates, leading to distinct propylene trimerization pathways on Ni and Fe sites, corroborating the earlier postulations regarding the reaction network. Based on the data provided, we have outlined the reaction routes involved in propylene trimerization (as illustrated in Fig. 10 ). According to the Cossee-Arlman mechanism, the M sites can incorporate carbon atoms from propylene in two distinct modes. Consequently, following two successive attacks, the M site can produce four different M-C6 intermediates (MR-1 to MR-4). These intermediates can undergo β-H elimination to yield dimers, as depicted in Fig. 10(a). Analysis of combined product distribution reveals that the majority of C6 is produced through the Cossee-Arlman mechanism, with the P1 and P3 pathways serving as primary routes. However, a minor presence of 3M2P in the C6 products suggests potential minor isomerization of the carbon chain during the reaction. Furthermore, differences in the stability of alkyl intermediates at Ni and Fe sites, as indicated by the results of C3H6-TPSR-MS experiments, have led to the presentation of two potential routes for trimer formation in Fig. 10(b). When propylene interacts with metal sites to generate M-C6 alkyl intermediates, they can undergo β-H elimination to form dimers, which subsequently react with propylene to form trimers (Route I). Alternatively, these M-C6 alkyl intermediates can continue reacting with propylene to form M-C9 alkyl intermediates, which then undergo β-H elimination to produce trimers (Route II). Notably, intermediates MR-1 and MR-3 in the primary pathways P1 and P3 of the Cossee-Arlman mechanism generate α-olefins through β-H elimination. These α-olefins can further engage in Route I, leading to the production of a specific type of C9 olefins (Type I C9), a feat that Route II cannot accomplish, as depicted in Fig. 10(c). The distribution and categorization of observed C6 and C9 olefins are displayed in Table 1, where Type I C6, Type II C6, Type I C9, and Type II C9 can be directly obtained through the Cossee-Arlman mechanism, while Type III C6 and Type III C9 may represent isomeric products, indicating potential chain isomerization during the reaction. The presence of Type I C9 in products catalyzed by Fe sites significantly is notably lower than that in products from Ni sites, suggesting a tendency for propylene trimerization on Fe sites towards Route II, while Ni sites exhibit a stronger inclination towards Route I. Moreover, the absence of Type I C6 and Type I C9 olefins in the products originating from Brönsted acid sites further confirms the theoretical basis of Ni and Fe metal-coordinated catalysis. 3.2.3 Stability evaluation The stability of 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 in propylene oligomerization reactions was evaluated, as depicted in Fig. 11 and Fig. S9. The catalyst displays a distinct induction phase within the initial 4 h, during which propylene conversion gradually rises from 95% to 98% and then keeps stable. Concurrently, as the reaction advanced, the selectivity towards C9 in the products diminishes gradually, while the selectivity towards C12 increases. This shift can be attributed to the continued oligomerization of the olefins. Throughout the stability testing period surpassing 80 h, the propylene conversion over the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample maintained around 98%, with the collective yield of C9 and C12 remaining at approximately 55%, and no notable deactivation is observed. Furthermore, to explore the physicochemical property changes of the catalyst during the reaction process, the N2 adsorption-desorption, TG-MS, and XPS characterizations were carried out by comparing the spent catalyst with the fresh catalyst. As depicted in Fig. S10 and Table S6, the spent sample manifested an augmentation in specific surface area and pore volume from 110 m2/g and 0.30 cm3/g to 120 m2/g and 0.38 cm3/g, likely stemming from the partial loss of active sites during the reaction. Moreover, the average pore diameter diminished from 4.9 to 3.4 nm, indicating carbon deposition-induced partial pore occlusion on the catalyst surface. The analysis of the TG-MS plot (Fig. 12 ) of the samples suggests that, in comparison to the fresh sample, the spent sample exhibited a lower weight loss rate after 600 °C compared to the fresh sample, indicating that during the reaction, certain weakly bound NiSO4 species may have been lost. Moreover, the emergence of a CO2 signal peak after 250 °C in the spent sample implies the occurrence of a certain degree of carbon deposition during the reaction. XPS characterization (Fig. 13 ) reveals a decrease in binding energies for both Ni and Fe species in the spent sample. This phenomenon could be attributed to the interaction of propylene molecules as electron donors, resulting in a reduction in the binding energies of the metallic active species during the reaction [57,58]. In light of this result, it is clear that despite the minor loss of active sites and carbon deposition observed during the reaction, a significant portion of highly effective and stable active sites remains catalyzing the propylene oligomerization process. This discovery is crucial for informing our future strategies in designing efficient and enduring catalysts for olefin oligomerization. 4 Conclusions In this work, the doping of Fe2O3 into the NiSO4/Al2O3 system results in the migration of SO4 2– to Fe3+, inducing alterations in the electronic states of divalent Ni2+ and Fe3+, as well as the surface acidity of the catalyst. It influences the oligomerization of propylene and the selectivity of products. The optimized 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 sample displays an excellent steady reaction rate of 48.5 mmolC3/(gcat.·h) and the highest yields of C9 and the combined C9 + C12, at 32.2% and 55.0%, respectively, which are much higher than those over NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst. The migration of sulfate ions on the surface of the doped catalyst not only results in an induction period at the beginning of the reaction but also forms active iron species, enhancing the trimer yield and transitioning the product distribution from a Schulz-Flory distribution to a Poisson distribution. By exploring the distribution of dimers and trimers, two routes for trimer formation according to the Cossee-Arlman mechanism are identified. The Fe2O3 doping favors the generation of trimers via Route II, resulting in an increase in the yield of Type II C9. Stability assessment conducted over 80 h suggests that, despite the existence of some loss of weakly bound active sites and challenges related to carbon deposition in the optimized catalyst, there has not been a significant deactivation observed. This study offers valuable insights into propylene trimer generation through the Cossee-Arlman pathway, setting the groundwork for the advancement of efficient catalysts for the selective oligomerization of propylene to produce fine chemicals. coredata.dc:description: Propylene, a readily accessible and economically viable light olefin, has garnered substantial interest for its potential conversion into valuable higher olefins through oligomerization processes. The distribution of products is profoundly influenced by the catalyst structure. In this study, Fe2O3-doped NiSO4/Al2O3 catalysts have been meticulously developed to facilitate the selective trimerization of propylene under mild conditions. Significantly, the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst demonstrates an enhanced reaction rate (48.5 mmolC3/(gcat.·h)), alongside a high yield of C9 (~ 32.2%), significantly surpassing the performance of the NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst (C9: ~24.1%). The incorporation of Fe2O3 modifies the migration process of sulfate ions, altering the Lewis acidity of the electron-deficient Ni and Fe sites on the catalyst and resulting a shift in product distribution from a Schulz-Flory distribution to a Poisson distribution. This shift is primarily ascribed to the heightened energy barrier for the β-H elimination reaction in the C6 alkyl intermediates on the doped catalyst, further promoting polymerization to yield a greater quantity of Type II C9. Furthermore, the validation of the Cossee-Arlman mechanism within the reaction pathway has been confirmed. It is noteworthy that the 0.25Fe2O3-NiSO4/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits remarkable stability exceeding 80 h in the selective trimerization of propylene. These research findings significantly enhance our understanding of the mechanisms underlying olefin oligomerization reactions and provide invaluable insights for the development of more effective catalysts.
